greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: A(n,k) = exponent of the largest power of n-th prime which divides k, square array read by antidiagonals.
comment: Square array A(n,k), where n = row, k = column, read by antidiagonals: A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), ... (transpose of array A060175).
A(n,k) is the (p_n)-adic valuation of k, where p_n is the n-th prime, A000040(n).
example: The top-left corner of the array:
A(1,8) = 3, because 2^3 is the largest power of 2 (= p_1 = A000040(1)) that divides 8.
a(2,9) = 2, because 3^2 is the largest power of 3 (= p_2) that divides 9.
a(3,15) = 1, because 5^1 is the largest power of 5 (= p_3) that divides 15.
program: (define (A249344bi row col) (let ((p (A000040 row))) (let loop ((n col) (i 0)) (cond ((not (zero? (modulo n p))) i) (else (loop (/ n p) (+ i 1)))))))
for n in range(1, 10): print([a(k, n - k + 1) for k in range(1, n + 1)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jun 24 2017
(PARI) a(n, k) = valuation(k, prime(n)); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 24 2017
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 28 2014
